oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Statistical Treatment of Pharmacokinetic Parameters
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Powers, Jean D.
Reiches, N. A.
Powers, T. E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: test statistic
probability distribution
pharmacokinetic parameters
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The choice of an appropriate test statistic for a given set of data is dependent on the degree to which the data fit a particular probability distribution. In this paper we consider other distributions as alternatives to the normal distribution in the study of certain pharmacokinetic parameters. It is well known that a symmetric confidence interval about the mean is appropriate only if the data follow a normal curve. This can be demonstrated readily by comparing 95% confidence intervals between a normal and a Chi-Square distribution, both of which have a mean of 50 and standard deviation of 10. (Figures 1 and 2) It is apparent that the assymmetry of the x2 distribution yields intervals of unequal distances on either side of the mean.
